title: 107_hr2920
content: The "Bulk Cash Smuggling Act of 2001" is the short title of this Act, which aims to address findings and purposes related to cash smuggling. The Congress finds that effective enforcement of currency reporting requirements has forced criminals to avoid traditional financial institutions, leading them to move large quantities of cash through ports of entry for smuggling. The transportation and smuggling of cash in bulk form is a common method of money laundering and a warning sign of various crimes. Large amounts of currency moved to circumvent reporting laws are equivalent to smuggling goods and contribute to criminal proceeds laundering efforts. The smuggling of bulk cash is a key part of criminal activity and can be effectively disrupted by confiscating the cash. Current penalties for currency reporting violations are not enough to deter money laundering, and making bulk cash smuggling a separate offense could allow for easier confiscation of the cash. The Act aims to criminalize bulk cash smuggling, authorize forfeiture of smuggled cash and other property involved, emphasize the seriousness of the offense, and provide guidelines for forfeiture amounts. The Act criminalizes bulk cash smuggling into or out of the United States. The Act criminalizes bulk cash smuggling involving amounts over $10,000 to evade currency reporting requirements within or outside the United States. The Act criminalizes currency smuggling within the United States, including concealing currency on a person or in belongings. Offenders face up to 5 years in prison and forfeiture of any property. The Act criminalizes currency smuggling within the United States, offenders face up to 5 years in prison and forfeiture of any property, real or personal, involved in the offense. The seizure, restraint, and forfeiture of property are governed by the Controlled Substances Act. If the forfeited property is unavailable, a personal money judgment may be entered against the defendant. Civil forfeiture applies to any property involved in a violation of the Act. The Act allows for the seizure and forfeiture of property involved in currency smuggling violations, following procedures similar to civil forfeitures in money laundering cases. The Act allows for the seizure and forfeiture of property involved in currency smuggling violations. The court can reduce the forfeiture if the currency was derived from a legitimate source and intended for a lawful purpose, to an amount not grossly disproportional to the offense's gravity. Factors considered include aggravating and mitigating circumstances. The Act allows for the seizure and forfeiture of property involved in currency smuggling violations, considering factors like the value of currency involved, efforts to conceal transactions, and whether it's part of a pattern of violations. SEC. 4 of the Act allows for forfeiture in currency reporting cases, specifically targeting bulk cash smuggling into or out of the United States. The court shall order the defendant to forfeit all property involved in certain violations and any traceable property. Forfeitures will follow procedures from the Controlled Substances Act. Civil forfeiture allows seizure of property related to the violations. Upon a showing by the property owner that currency involved in the offense was from a legitimate source and intended for lawful purposes, the court shall reduce the forfeiture to a proportionate amount. Factors will be considered in determining the reduction. In determining the amount of forfeiture, the court considers aggravating and mitigating factors related to the gravity of the offense, including the value of currency involved, efforts to conceal property, and whether the offense is part of a pattern of repeated violations of Federal law. Section 981(a)(1)(A) and Section 982(a)(1) of title 18, United States Code, are amended by removing references to specific sections of title 31.
